item.category: NYSC Soon To Be Optional For Nigerian Graduates - DG
item.description: The Director-General of National Youth Service Corps (NYSC), Brigadier-General Johnson Olawumi, yesterday 5th of August, said the Federal government is set to make the youth service programme optional for Nigerian graduates. Speaking at a meeting with President Buhari on Wednesday, Olawumi said there were plans to make the scheme voluntary and reduce the corps population [...]
item.content:encoded:
The Director-General of National Youth Service Corps (NYSC), Brigadier-General Johnson Olawumi, yesterday 5th of August, said the Federal government is set to make the youth service programme optional for Nigerian graduates.

Speaking at a meeting with President Buhari on Wednesday, Olawumi said there were plans to make the scheme voluntary and reduce the corps population to make the programme more sustainable and effective in its course.

Moreover, Permanent Secretary of the Federal Ministry of Youth Development, Mrs. Rabi Jimeta had said that the annual enrolment of corps participants from 2,364 at establishment in 1974 had increased to 229,016 in 2014.

Mrs Jimeta said: “Given the increasing number of tertiary institutions, our projection is that the number of corps participants may rise to 300,000 by year 2020.”

President Buhari assured that his administration will ensure the continuity and the betterment of the NYSC service scheme.

He said: “I firmly believe in NYSC and I think it should remain a national programme to promote integration. Whenever I go home to Daura, I look out for corps members from Lagos, Aba and other parts of the country.”

“I am always thrilled to learn that except for the NYSC, some of them have never left their states of origin to visit other cities in the country,” the President added.

item.content:encoded:
A lecturer at the University Of Lagos (UNILAG), Afeez Baruwa, has been arrested for allegedly raping an 18-year-old girl, identified as Caroline in the Yaba areaof Lagos.

According to reports, the lecturer and Caroline’s father belonged to the same landlords’ association at Abesan, Ipaja. It was gathered that the victim’s father had allowed her daughter to follow the lecturer on July 23, to UNILAG for an admission process.

Speaking to correspondent, the Director of the Office of the Public Defender, Mrs. Omotola Rotimi said: “the victim’s father wanted the lecturer to assist with his daughter’s admission. On the fateful day, the girl left with the lecturer as early as 5.30am, and they got to the school at about 7am.”No one had arrived at the hall except a woman. While the exams had yet to start, It was learnt that Baruwa allegedly took the girl inside one of the study halls, bolted the door, and raped her.

She went home, and the father found out that her daughter had been raped. He took her to the Mirabel Centre, which then informed the OPD. The centre also contacted the police at the Surulere and Isokoko divisions, and the suspect was arrested.”

Mrs Rotimi said the OPD would write a letter to the UNILAG Vice-Chancellor on the incident, so as to avoid a reoccurrence.

A Police official said the lecturer “confessed to the act, but his claim is that the sex was by mutual consent.”

Baruwa claims to be a part-time lecturer, but not an employee of the University of Lagos, according to the Lagos State Police Public Relations Officer, DSP Patricia Amadin.

item.dc:creator: Anu Odusote
item.description: President Muhammadu Buhari on Wednesday, August 5, 2015, ordered the Ministry of Aviation to expedite action on the establishment of a new national airline. Buhari gave the order at the Presidential Villa when he was briefed by officials of the Aviation Ministry led by the Permanent Secretary, Binta Bello. Erstwhile national carrier, Nigeria Airways, established [...]
item.content:encoded:
President Muhammadu Buhari on Wednesday, August 5, 2015, ordered the Ministry of Aviation to expedite action on the establishment of a new national airline.

Buhari gave the order at the Presidential Villa when he was briefed by officials of the Aviation Ministry led by the Permanent Secretary, Binta Bello.

Erstwhile national carrier, Nigeria Airways, established in 1958, was liquidated in 2003 in under heavy debts, mismanagement, inefficiency and corruption.

Addressing State House correspondents after the briefing, Bello said the President was actually worried about Nigeria not having a national air carrier, hence the instruction to re-establish one.

The ministry officials also briefed Buhari on the challenges domestic airlines were facing despite Federal Government’s N300 billion intervention fund to enable them boost their operations.

Bello disclosed that the airlines were incidentally hugely indebted to regulatory agencies under the Aviation Ministry, among other issues that have left some of the airlines still struggling to maintain optimum operational capabilities.

The Permanent Secretary announced that the four state-of-the-art airport terminals across the country being constructed with a Chinese Bank loan will be ready by the first quarter of 2016.

She stressed that the facilities under construction and expansion would be big and modern enough to accommodate large aircraft like the Airbus 380 aeroplanes as obtains in the largest international airports.

The President also instructed the ministry to begin the process of relinquishing airspace and radar control of neighbouring countries as they now have the capacity to cover their own airspace.

Bello reassured Nigerians and the international community that Nigeria’s airspace ?is safe and has just recorded a score of over 90 per cent by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO).

According to the police, the suspect was said to have collected Ajala’s ATM [...]
item.content:encoded:
A 20-year-old student of the College of Education in Oyo State, Olajide Ajayi, has been arrested by the state Police Command for attempting to murder his niece, Opeyemi Ajala, by cutting her throat after he deceived her and stole her school fees.

According to the police, the suspect was said to have collected Ajala’s ATM card with the intention of withdrawing the sum of N47,000 to help her pay her school fees which he instead used to buy clothes and spend on his girlfriend.

When the niece, also a student of the institution, asked him for the teller with which he paid in the money, he began to develop a plan to kill her when he could no longer bear the pressure from her.

In a bid to cover up his theft, on the night of  the incident, Ajayi went to Ajala’s house with a knife, sneaked into her room where she was sleeping, and proceeded to slit her throat with the knife where he left her for dead.

Unfortunately for him, Ajala lady did not die and she managed to alert her neighbours who rushed her to the University College of Hospital, Ibadan, and reported the case to the police.

During his interrogation, Ajayi confessed to his crime.

“I collected the money, but I spent it. When the pressure from her was too much, and there was no way I could get the money to pay her back, I decided to kill her. One night, I went to her house with a sharp knife to kill her.
I got to her house at about 8 pm; when I entered the room, I locked the door and pinned her head down on the bed. I did not allow her to shout. Then, I brought out the knife and slit her throat. When blood started gushing out and she was unconscious, I thought she was dead and I escaped.”

item.content:encoded:
Outspoken Ekiti State Governor, Ayodele Fayose, on Wednesday swerved at the Federal Government anti-corruption stance, describing it as mere noise-making, witch-hunt and diversionary tactic to hoodwink the public into overlooking the seeming failure of the government to deliver on its electoral promises.

Speaking through his Special Assistant on Public Communications and New Media, Lere Olayinka, the Governor said: “You don’t announce a process to the public. Rather, you announce the results because that is what is of interest to the people. It is like you are announcing that you know where armed robbers reside, won’t they change their location?”

“What the All Progressives Congress (APC) spin-doctors and their collaborators in the Presidency are doing is simple. It is such that when there is nothing to tell the people as per the rising Boko Haram attacks, Dollar and other foreign currencies exchange rates, petrol pump price and other seeming failed promises of the APC federal government, they will accuse former President Goodluck Jonathan and his men of corruption, insult Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) and make noise about fighting corruption.”

Governor Fayose maintained that: “If President Muhammadu Buhari knows exactly where the stolen funds are kept and who looted the funds, he does not need all these public announcements. Rather, he should make public names of the looters and bring back the purported stolen funds, location of which he has identified. It is when he is able to bring back the money that he should make announcements of recovered funds.”

Challenging Buhari to start the anti-corruption fight from his party, starting with those that aided the President during his campaign, Fayose said: “Some of those who sponsored the President’s election have not done any other jobs apart from holding public offices. Yet, they provided private jets and funds with which the President campaigned across the length and breadth of Nigeria. He should let Nigerians know where they got money to buy private jets and the several billions of naira spent on his election.”

“Mr President and his men should know that these planned efforts to brand PDP as a party of corrupt people and supress the giant strides of the Jonathan administration won’t work because Nigerians know that APC is peopled with more corrupt people and the President must treat the issue of corruption without looking at political parties,” the Ekiti state governor added.

item.content:encoded:
The Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) on Monday arraigned a Bawa Momodu before Justice I. E. Ekwo of the Federal High Court sitting in Port Harcourt, Rivers State. Bawa who, until the incident, was an employee at Sterling Bank has been accused of stealing N27 million from a customer’s account. He is faced with a 16-count charge bordering on forgery, uttering and stealing to the tune of N27 million.

According to the Head on Media and Publicity to the anti-graft agency commission, Wilson Uwujaren, the accused allegedly forged the signature of the said account holder and fraudulently withdrew the money from the bank.

“Investigations further revealed that the said amount was transferred to the Sterling Bank account of one Emilia Ugwandu, who is now at large, in a bid to hide the source of the stolen funds,” Uwujaren said.

However, Momodu pleaded not guilty to the charges preferred against him. In view of his plea, the prosecution counsel, A. Olatunji, asked for a date for the commencement of trial.

Consequently, the defence counsel, Allen Nwogwama, prayed the court to grant his client bail. Ekwo granted the accused bail in the sum N7 million and one surety in like sum. The surety must be a responsible member of the society with landed property worth the bail sum, to be verified by the court registrar and the prosecution.

The accused is also to be reporting at the EFCC office on the last day of every month.

DSP Amadin, who identified the deceased officer as Lukas Abashi, disclosed that the driver of the vehicle with Reg. No. ANC 66 XA escaped after the accident. She said the police officer died on the spot after the tanker ran him over.

Lagos State Governor, Mr. Akinwunmi Ambode, on Wednesday 5th of August, swore in the 19 new Permanent Secretaries, charging them to guide against anything that could compromise standard of government in the course of their duties.

The brief ceremony which was held at the State House, Ikeja, was witnessed by family members, friends and associates of the new permanent secretaries.

The Governor in his address said the quality of service delivered by the government would be measured on daily basis, stressing that “any ministry where the quality of service is compromised, the permanent secretary, as Accounting Officer, would be held liable.”
